sen.j: 池坊 専慶（いけのぼう せんけい、生没年不詳）は、室町時代中期の京都頂法寺（六角堂）池坊の僧侶。
sen.e: Senkei IKENOBO (the date of his birth and death is not clear) was a Buddhist priest of Kyoto Choho-ji Temple (Rokkakudo) who was active in the middle of Muromachi Period.

sen.j: 文明 (日本)年間（1469年-1487年）立花（たてばな）の上手として有名となり、京都東福寺の僧月渓聖澄による「百瓶華序」（1600年に成立）によると池坊の流祖とする。
sen.e: He became famous during the period from 1469 till 1487 as a superior of Tatebana and according to "Hyakubinkajo" (completed in 1600) compiled by Shocho GEKKEI, a buddhist monk of Kyoto Tofuku-ji Temple, he is deemed as the founder of Ikenobo school.

He became famous during the period from 1469 until 1487 as a superior of Tatebana (standing flowers) and according to 'Hyakuhei Kanojo' (records of flower arrangement by a hundred people) (completed in 1600) compiled by Shocho GEKKEI, a Buddhist monk of Kyoto Tofuku-ji Temple, he is deemed as the founder of Ikenobo School.

sen.j: 禅僧大極が記した「碧山日録」（1459年-1463年、1465年-1468年）によれば、1462年（寛正3年）近江国守護佐々木氏に招かれて金瓶に草花数十枝を挿し、洛中の好事家が競って見物したという。
sen.e: According to "hekisannichiroku" (1459 - 1464, 1465 - 1468) written by Zen priest Taikyoku, Senkei in 1462 arranged tens of flowers in a golden vase responding to the invitation of Sasaki clan, shugo (constable) of Omi-no-Kuni, and many of dilettantes inside the capital competed in seeing it.
